positive.review:
It was one of the first games I played on my PlayStation 4 back in the day. I replayed it recently, about ten years later, and it‚Äôs just as fun as I remembered, maybe even more so.

First of all, Kyrat is beautiful, and I mean beautiful. This game doesn‚Äôt look like it‚Äôs from 2014. The views are breathtaking, and the setting feels truly unique. It really makes you feel like an outsider in a foreign land.

The gunplay is solid. There‚Äôs a wide variety of weapons to try out, but truth be told, I stuck with just a few favorites for most of the game.

There‚Äôs also a ton of side content to do. I genuinely enjoyed 100%ing the game, but I‚Äôd be lying if I said I didn‚Äôt feel a bit of fatigue after collecting my 40th mask, tearing down my 130th poster, or repeating yet another side mission.

The voice acting is phenomenal, especially after making story choices. I actually felt bad after siding with Sabal once, thanks to the amazing performance by Amita‚Äôs voice actress. That said, it‚Äôs a bit questionable that the characters reveal their true motives and tell you how badly you messed up after you‚Äôve already made your choice.

Pagan Min is wonderful. He‚Äôs charismatic, funny, and I always enjoyed listening to him whenever he showed up, same goes for several of the other characters.

The story is solid overall, though there‚Äôs one part at the airport that I didn‚Äôt really care about. It could‚Äôve been handled or explained differently.

The Arena is fun, but grinding it to rank 10 for the unique weapon was definitely tedious.

I also tried the multiplayer for the achievement  it‚Äôs pretty much dead, but I‚Äôm not surprised, since it didn‚Äôt seem particularly interesting.

All in all, I can highly recommend this game. It‚Äôs my favorite Far Cry title, and I‚Äôll definitely revisit it again at some point in the future.

TLDR;
I generally like Far Cry games. beautiful vistas, cool guns, nature, interesting villains, if you too like the concept I can recommend this. But out of all of the Far crys this is probably the second worst for me. It's not bad, but the others are better. 

Okay, THE GOOD: Kyrat is a pretty place. 
Music is cool, especialy in the Yogi missions. 

THE BAD,:

The 'Leaving mission area. Mission will fail' message.

You can't loot bodies unless standing at a certain angle. Swapping your weapon and looting bodies are bound to the same button, which would be fine if loot was tap, swap was hold, but no, they are both hold button. Interaction prompts are constantly bugged out, sometimes you can takedown enemies from a mile away, sometimes you don't get a prompt at all. 

Abysmal loading times on an SSD and sub 60 fps drops on hardware that's 10 years newer than this game. Especially bad if youtake the camera out.

Unskippable cutscenes, combined with Cutscene every time you restart a mission.

Game often forgets to create a checkpoint. Like, after travelling 2000 meters to a compound for a mission, dying, and putting you back to where you started. (often save manually instead, trust me)

There's a fake FOV slider, fake because it doesn't show the actual value and maxing it out still looks like it's sub 80. Even after tweaking the ini file it feels off.

Stealth is completely busted, kill one isolated enemy far away from everyone, but if they spot you for a nanosecond, the entire map will suddenly know where you are. Forget chain takedowns entirely. Just shoot everyone with a sniper from very far away.

Speaking of, bullets disappear when sniping from a certain distance. 

Civvie running into the side of your car dying, -50 karma.

Typical uninspired ubislop collectibles. IMO collectibles should have a function in games, not just collect it for the sake of artificially padding out game time. 

Can't fly over mountains, invisible walls repelling the heli. Flying from Utkarsh to the southeast road doesn't even let you fly above the trees. And these limitations seem utterly useless because you can just go around stuff, and it's anti-fun.

Chopper killing you instantly if it tilts even the slightest while landing. 

Animals suckerpunching you from behind, like a rhino or eagle is fun and 'haha so random' for the first 3 times but it gets massively annoying very quickly.

Achievement is called: The sky is falling. 
Description: perform a takedown from a buzzer.
You fly over an enemy, and do a death from above, doesn't work...
You have to fly next to a vehicle and do a vehicle takedown from the side. THEN WHY THE F IS IT CALLED THE SKY IS FALLING?! I'm pissed because it was quite the achievement to position the buzzer so you can fall on an enemy, and it was massively diappointing to not get the achi for it. The vehicle takedown was much easier. 

Wingsuit somemetimes randomly becomes unavailable. I hope you enjoy falling to your death.

DLC Dependent Achievements.

The side-quests get repetitive. For example for Longinus you will be doing the same quest over and over again. Yogi's are a bit more creative but it's still just go to checkpoints a bunch of times. 

The combat in Shangri-la is just plain awful (till you get the bow shotgun upgrade). Cool bossfight tho.

Steam counts the ubisoft launcher as play time. So if you forget to close it, congrats, FC4 is now your one of your most played games. I certainly didn't play it for 83 hours. Maybe that's why everyone wants their own launchers.

This is my fifth playthrough and I'm going for 100%. Far Cry 4 is my second-favourite game of all time (first is Minecraft). One thing I love about it is how perfectly balanced the open-world size is for a story-driven game. It‚Äôs big enough to explore but not so massive that it pulls you away from the main story. A lot of modern open-world games lose that balance ‚Äî but Far Cry 4 nails it.
Far Cry 4 offers stunning scenery, chaotic gunfights, and enough accidental self-inflicted disasters to qualify as a personality trait.

(Game #16 of my 2025 100% Marathon.)
Far Cry 4 feels like the most polished and cohesive entry to the franchise. The world is jaw-droppingly beautiful at times, showcasing a level of verticality that we don't often see in open world games. The player character and central story are not as interesting as those of Far Cry 3, but the role you play in determining Kyrat's fate through involvement with Amita and Sabal makes up for it, in my opinion. Gunplay is similar to FC3, but still improved in little ways. A 100% run won't force you to do too much extra content, once again taking you to about 75% of the content in exchange for all Steam achievements.

Far Cry 4 takes the formula from the third game and refines it. The Himalayan setting is beautiful, and the world feels dense and full of things to do. The story isn‚Äôt as iconic as in Far Cry 3, but the main antagonist is still interesting, and the gameplay is polished and satisfying.
If you enjoy open-world action games with lots of freedom, this one is definitely worth playing.

In short, I have a hate and love relationship with this game. It is simultaneously one of the best games and one of the worst games I have played.

I love the setting of Kyrat. Beautiful scenery, eastern religion and mysticism, and decently believable settlements. Rabi Ray Rana's broadcast and ramblings are pretty entertaining.
I hate the setting of Kyrat. Landing with the parachute is janky and irritating a lot of the time, I stumbled upon bad collision on more than one occasion, and the grappling hook system can be a bit janky.

The game has more bugs than its predecessor. I don't know if this is a Proton thing or not. Aiming down sights or anything else that requires you to hold down RMB can make you feel like Ajay has arthritis or some other ailment: using the mortar was an absolute nightmare. Thankfully you don't need to aim down sights with any of the firearms, hip firing is totally valid despite this not being a 90s game.
Some unknown locations simply don't register. Like with the ADS conundrum, swimming/diving fast by holding shift also doesn't seem to work properly. You have to essentially do really long presses instead of holding the button down indefinitely.
Skill issue, maybe, but stealth felt way more brutal and borderline broken at times when compared to the last game.

Spoilers below. You have been warned.

I love the story of Far Cry 4. Pagan Min is an excellent anti-hero-ish character, and it is a shame how little screentime (including his radio messages to Ajay) he got. But even more underutilized were the goons working for Min. Paul and Noore were pretty much just names in the game. Yuma was a bit more memorable than the other two.
Mr. Chiffon's side quests were awesome. As a minor character he was still very memorable, and I love him yapping about fashion and the definition of fierceness. A giant improvement over FC3's billboards.
Yogi and Reggie were pricks, they pricked me, then paid me. Thanks for the free dope I guess?
Shangri-La was pretty good. The takedowns felt way better than the base game's, simply by making them usable more often. The tiger was pretty cute.
The other side content is nothing special, but some of the dialogue, particularly in the Armed Escort missions, was good.

I hate the story of Far Cry 4. The Golden Path felt like two idiots fighting, and ironically the real Golden Path would've been to keep the traditions a la Sabal while growing poppies and abolishing the practice of the Tarun Matara and promoting gender equality a la Amita. The whole game I wished I could've joined forces with Pagan.
I wish that Ajay was a bit more talkative. Maybe not like Jason was, but a little more would've gone a long way.
Willis has two special powers: backstabbing the player and fluorescence.
I don't like Longinus' dialogue. And except for the Himalayas mission, they were all lukewarm.
Yogi and Reggie are British.

Overall, this game has a special place in my heart, and I love it despite its flaws and irritating moments.

[h1]Far Cry 4 Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
A solid Far Cry that does exactly what you expect. It looks good, plays fine, and gives you a big checklist playground. It does not meaningfully push the series forward, but if you like the loop you will have a good time.

[hr]
[h1]What It Is[/h1]
You are Ajay Ghale returning to Kyrat, a Himalayan nation torn between Pagan Min‚Äôs regime and a rebel faction. You liberate outposts and fortresses, hunt wildlife to upgrade gear, collect resources, and choose how to help the resistance while the story nudges you between key missions.

[hr]
[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
Kyrat is beautiful and varied. Snowy peaks, forest valleys, hilltop shrines, and cliff roads feel alive with civilians, patrols, wildlife, and random skirmishes. The map size is just right for roaming. Radio towers and viewpoints deliver great vistas. Visuals hold up well for the era.

[hr]
[h1]Combat and Tools[/h1]
Gunplay is competent. Bows, ARs, SMGs, LMGs, shotguns, pistols, and a few signature guns cover most styles. Stealth with takedowns, bait, and alarms feels familiar from Far Cry 3. Nothing wildly new, but it works.

[hr]
[h1]Systems and Side Content[/h1]
Traditional Ubisoft mix: outposts, fortresses, hunting, races, hostage rescues, propaganda posters, collectibles. Loads to do, sometimes too much. Expect repetition if you chase 100 percent or achievements. Arena mode is fun for a bit, but grinding to rank 10 can drag. Multiplayer lobbies are mostly inactive today, so plan boosting if you care about those trophies.

[hr]
[h1]Story and Villain[/h1]
The plot is basic but serviceable. Pagan Min is the standout, a stylish and charismatic antagonist who elevates cutscenes even if he is not quite Vaas-level iconic. Faction choice moments add flavor rather than deep consequences.

[hr]
[h1]Performance and Polish[/h1]
Runs well on modern hardware for a 2014 release. Occasional jank is there, but nothing show stopping.

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]
[list]
[*] Striking Himalayan setting with wildlife and constant ambient activity
[*] Satisfying stealth outpost clears and fortress assaults
[*] Big toybox of weapons and vehicles
[*] Pagan Min steals scenes and adds personality
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]What Falls Short[/h1]
[list]
[*] Feels very close to Far Cry 3 in structure and mechanics
[*] Side content gets repetitive fast if you do everything
[*] Arena grind and inactive multiplayer for achievement hunters
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Recommended with expectations set. If you want a classic Far Cry loop in a gorgeous new location, Far Cry 4 delivers. If you were hoping for bold changes or a reinvention, this plays it safe. Best enjoyed by focusing on the main path with a curated slice of side activities.

Farcry 4 is one of the best games of the mid 2010's in my book. Essentially, I'd place it neck and neck with the predecessor, Farcry 3. The story is engaging, the lore is solid, progression through it really makes you question the morality behind your choices and which side in the civil war you're supporting, the action is intense and the - "EAGLE!!!!!1111" - never fails to get a laugh out of me. 

So why did I give it a thumbs down? It has nothing to do with the game itself - but with the software launcher. Ubisoft REQUIRES you to download and then launch the game via their crappy, unnecessary third party software, even when you purchase the game through Steam. Their garbage app crashed my PC seemingly every THIRD time I went to launch and play the game. Why does Steam even allow this? 

Farcry 4 is amazing. I'd recommend any fan of the series, or of action RPG shooters to give it a try. But I'd rather go get a used PS4 or Xbone and play it on there rather than risk any further damage to my PC, thanks to the terrible 3rd party app required to play it. This will, sadly - given their repertoire of other classic 2000s and 2010s titles I'd love to replay - be my first, last and ONLY Ubisoft purchase on Steam.

As both a long-time gamer and an investor, I look at products through two lenses: quality of experience and business sustainability. Ubisoft is currently failing at both.

The Privacy Issue: This "game" is essentially spyware wrapped in a launcher. The moment you install it, you are forced to agree to a Terms of Service that allows Ubisoft to harvest your personal data‚Äîincluding usage habits, IP location, and hardware specs‚Äîand share it with "trusted partners" (advertisers and data brokers).

They are not just selling you a product but a  temporary license to play; they are selling YOU to third parties.

Forced Third-Party Account: You cannot play this single-player game without logging into Ubisoft Connect, which exists solely to track engagement metrics and feed their data pipeline.

 "Active Sharing": Buried in their settings is an option called "Active Sharing" which defaults to sharing your personal info with companies like Facebook and LiveRamp.

Telemetry: Even in single-player, the client sends hundreds of packets to external analytics servers (Google, Amazon, Datadog) to track your behavior.

The Investor Perspective: From a business standpoint, this strategy is disastrous. Ubisoft is trading long-term brand loyalty for short-term data monetization. They are alienating their core customer base to chase "whales" and sell user data. This is why their stock is at a 10-year low. A company that treats its paying customers as data points to be harvested rather than people to be entertained is a failing company.

Conclusion: I refunded this immediately. Do not support this anti-consumer practice. If you value your privacy and digital ownership, do not buy this.

Final Verdict: 0/10 - Refunded due to invasive data policies.

Very torn ont his one. I greatly enjoyed the previous game, but this is just such a mixed bag. The main story is simply not interesting at all. I have no connection to any of the characters, I've already forgot all of their names. Even the villain is so boring, just some blond cocky guy and that's it. The main quests are not special at all, I enjoyed the side content far more, since it's straight forward without needing to listen to badly written characters talking about things that don't interest me at all. Even the Shangri-La quests were not my cup of tea, visually it was beautiful, but it just took me out of the game so much.

The writing is literaly garbage, I had a radio call at one point and the guy started to talk about how my character must have an itchy asshole, because he's on a mission all the time... It's just so offputting. There are some improvements in the gameplay, I really enjoyed piloting the buzzers and most of the grappling hook segments. The gliding could have been better, but it was not horrible in general.

I also liked the additional events in the open world, it almost made the place feel more alive, but kind of fails at it too, since the NPCs are so unaware of everything, that it takes that away immediately (eg. frendlies driving into your car all the time).

In short, if you are playing for anything besides the gunplay or stealthily taking out camps, then you will probably not enjoy this game at all.

Very torn ont his one. I greatly enjoyed the previous game, but this is just such a mixed bag. The main story is simply not interesting at all. I have no connection to any of the characters, I've already forgot all of their names. Even the villain is so boring, just some blond cocky guy and that's it. The main quests are not special at all, I enjoyed the side content far more, since it's straight forward without needing to listen to badly written characters talking about things that don't interest me at all. Even the Shangri-La quests were not my cup of tea, visually it was beautiful, but it just took me out of the game so much.

The writing is literaly garbage, I had a radio call at one point and the guy started to talk about how my character must have an itchy asshole, because he's on a mission all the time... It's just so offputting. There are some improvements in the gameplay, I really enjoyed piloting the buzzers and most of the grappling hook segments. The gliding could have been better, but it was not horrible in general.

I also liked the additional events in the open world, it almost made the place feel more alive, but kind of fails at it too, since the NPCs are so unaware of everything, that it takes that away immediately (eg. frendlies driving into your car all the time).

In short, if you are playing for anything besides the gunplay or stealthily taking out camps, then you will probably not enjoy this game at all.
